captions.text:
Now, feeding your Tiger Salamander is very
easy. I recommend using your trusty forceps

right here. It's easier to use it than to
try to feed them with your fingers. These

guys have teeth but they aren't sharp enough
to damage your skin. Their jaw pressure isn't

enough to hurt you. It does kind of feel like
sandpaper rubbing on your finger. But again,

use forceps because it's a lot easier to do.
Grab the food item, in this case a small cockroach.

Now all I have to pretty much do is put it
right in front of the Tiger Salamander. I'm

going to feed this big one right over here.
And once he sees it coming, they grab it and

they just do the rest. Now, these guys don't
chew their food, they just swallow it whole.

And we'll feed this one over here. And don't
feed your Tiger Salamander too much. That's

pretty much all they need for one day. Tiger
Salamanders, if you feed them too much food,

they can get a little obese. Some people feed
their salamander’s pinky mice, which is

fine every now and then. But pinky mice are
filled with their mother's milk and their

mother's milk is very fattening. So in thus,
pinkies are very fattening especially if you

feed them every single day to your salamander
which is not an actively moving animal. They

don't burn off a lot of calories very quickly.
Feeding pinky mice to your salamander all

the time, you are going to get a big, fat,
obese salamander resulting in an unhealthy

salamander. I feed mine mostly cockroaches,
crickets, and every now and then some meal

worms. And if you need to fatten up your Tiger
Salamander, if you purchased a Tiger Salamander

that's very thin, then you can plump it up
with some small pinky mice. Of course, feed

them frozen thawed pinky mice, don't feed
them live mice and that will help put some
meat on your Tiger Salamander's bones.

title: How to Care for a Pet Tiger Salamander : How to Feed Tiger Salamanders
